[Intro: John Lennon]
 I Dig a Pygmy by Charles Hawtrey and the Deaf Aids
 Phase one, in which Doris gets her oats

This is typical nonsense chatter from John Lennon, who had a twisted sense of humor. “Pygmy” is a generic term for ethnic groups that have a short average height, although it classically refers to the Pygmy People of Western Congo.

Charles Hawtrey was an old-hat comic actor in the ‘60s, “deaf aids” is British English for hearing aids, and “getting one’s oats” means to have sex. Lennon is thus humorously introducing the song as if it were a movie by Charles Hawtrey and the unlikely “Deaf Aids” called I Dig a Pygmy.

Also, the May 1970 Let It Be film shows John saying this phrase. It appears to have been edited into the beginning of the song. All in all, it’s just another joke from John Lennon.

Two of us wearing raincoats, standing solo
 In the sun

Might be a nod to the cover of Help!, where both Lennon and McCartney are literally wearing raincoats in the sun.



The use of “raincoat” instead of the British “mac"—like in “Penny Lane”—is probably aimed to fit with the American folk/western feel of the song.
You and me chasing paper, getting nowhere

This is another line that suggests the song is about Paul McCartney’s relationship with John Lennon. “Chasing paper” typically refers to earning money, although in this line they are trying to earn money and are “getting nowhere,” which doesn’t sound like The Beatles at all.

Around the time of the Get Back sessions, the Beatles were embroiled in numerous lawsuits over their contracts. There’s a reference to this in “You Never Give Me Your Money,” with a similar line, about bank statements and receipts:

You never give me your money
You only give me your funny paper

You and I have memories
 Longer than the road that stretches out ahead

These lyrics became strangely prophetic with the murder of John Lennon in 1980 – Paul met John in 1957, and “Two Of Us” was recorded in 1969. 12 years had already passed for them, but they would only have 11 years for their future.



Additionally, ‘longer than the road that stretches out ahead’ is an odd lyrics if the song is about Eastman. McCartney met Linda only two years prior the recording of this song (1967).

Paul had known Lennon for far longer and shared a precious relationship with him that encompassed teenage play, the start of The Quarrymen in 1957, and the start of the Beatles.
You and me burning matches, lifting latches

This is another lyric that seems to be referring to John Lennon, not Linda Eastman, as drinking and smoking together was an early Beatles pastime.

In Liverpudlian bars of the ‘50s and '60s, it was considered good etiquette to buy someone else’s first drink. This was called “lifting the latch.” After that, you could get other people to buy drinks for you.

By the time Paul and Linda met, neither would have been terribly concerned about getting their drinks cheaply.

You and me Sunday driving, not arriving
 On our way back home

This seems to be a reference to The Beatles' December 1965 hit song, “Day Tripper”:

She was a day tripper
Sunday driver, yeah

Sunday driving typically refers to casual trips taken on a lazy Sunday afternoon.
